facts.fact: At a convergent boundary between two continental plates, neither plate goes under into the mantle (because continental plates are less dense than the underlying mantle).
As the plates move toward each other, the crust crumples from the stress and rises up to form mountains.

At a divergent boundary between two oceanic plates, an underwater mountain range forms because of pressure from the rising magma below. The mountain range has a deep crack called a rift valley at its top.
As the plates move, the two sides of the mountain range are carried away from the rift valley.
Magma wells up from the Earth's interior to fill the rift.
The magma is rapidly cooled by the sea and solidifies into rock, creating new ocean floor.
At a transform boundary between two continental plates, the two plates are sliding past each other.
The two plates do not move smoothly past each other because of friction.
When friction prevents plate movement, the energy of movement (kinetic energy) becomes “trapped” or stored at the boundary as elastic strain.
When enough energy, or strain, builds up, the plates are able to move.
The movement releases the stored up energy in the form of seismic waves, which result in earthquakes.
